summary: On September 14, 2018, the Missouri Court of Appeals entered a final judgment against Missourians to Protect the Missouri Constitution, finding that the Missouri Initiative Petition violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The court also found that the Initiative Petition was defective for failing to accurately identify the provisions of the federal law that govern the allocation of state legislative districts.  According to the court's order, filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Missouri, the proposed amendment would impose a two-year waiting period before legislators and legislative employees could serve as paid lobbyists, and require the commission to adopt a final reapportionment plan by the end of the calendar year.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the Commission has agreed to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins the Commission from violating these provisions, and orders the Commission to pay a civil penalty in the amount of $2,500. The Commission has also agreed to pay $1,500 in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties.  In a separate administrative proceeding, the court issued a temporary restraining order against Ritter and Mehan, ordering them to comply with the Commission’s order, and ordering the Commission not to violate the anti-fraud provision of the Commission Act.  On September 19, 2018 the court granted the Commission the right to respond to a request for an emergency court order and issued an order suspending the Commission and ordering it to conduct a hearing on the matter.  A hearing for the Commission is scheduled for October 17, 2018.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-5221. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Missouri Attorney General's Office and the Missouri Secretary of State's Office. Â The Commission's Office of Inspector General has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool onÂ SEC.gov.Â On November 6, 2019, the SEC issued a subpoena for a copy of the SEC's complaint filed in federal court in Missouri.   The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by Michael J. Burt and supervised by Eric R. Werner. The litigation will be led by Jennifer C. McKinley and Mr. Werner, and the case is being supervised by Kelly L. Gibson. The case has been supervised by C.J. Kerstetter. The Office of Compliance and Advocacy has issued aÂ Complaint
